subclassFeature.name: College of Dance
entries: The College of Dance is one of the oldest colleges to still practice the bardic arts. There is a wide schism that separates this college from the others. This is due to their performance, which does not rely on song, instruments, or sound at all, but dance.

Bards of this college are often simply referred to as Dancers, but the roles they play are anything but simple. There are Dancers who perform holy dances used in prayer; there are Dancers who tell stories and keep history alive through their performances; and there are those who dance in the very battlefield, mixing performance with combat, lifting the spirits of their companions and allowing them to perform feats beyond their normal capacities. These Bards use dance to become a blur in the enemy’s eyes, dodging their attacks with expert grace and poise and clouding their minds with enchanting movements that make the Dancer harder to pin down.
It takes courage to stand in the thick of battle among armed warriors and armored Paladins, but it takes a Bard to do so while dancing.

subclassFeature.name: Somatic Performance
entries: You are able to cast your magic using only the precise, meticulous, and elegant movements of your body. You may choose to replace all Verbal or Material components of a spell with only the Somatic component of dancing, so long as the material components of the spell do not have a cost.

subclassFeature.name: Dance
entries: You can perform an arcane dance that empowers and inspires an ally in combat. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can start your Dance and choose one creature you can see within 15 feet of you. Roll your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die. That creature can now add the result of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} roll to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw per round. On the next turn, the creature you inspired can add your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} roll again, so long as it remains within 15 feet of you and you keep dancing. The {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} bonus decreases by one at the end of each of your turns.

For instance: You use your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to start your Dance and select an ally within 15 feet of you. You roll a 6 on your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die. The creature you're inspiring attacks an enemy and adds +6 to their attack roll. After the end of your next turn, the creature you're inspiring now adds +5 to their attack against that enemy. The creature you're inspiring adds +4 in the next round, then +3, and so on, until the {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} bonus is reduced to 0.
A creature automatically loses all benefits of your Dance when they leave its 15-foot radius.

You can renew the dance by using your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to expend another use of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} and re-roll your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die. You must concentrate on this Dance as if it is a spell, and cannot cast any spells that require {@status concentration} while using this ability.
You can end your Dance at any point during your turn without using an action or Bonus Action.

subclassFeature.name: Deadly Dance
entries: Your calculated movements blend dance with battle prowess, allowing you to double your attack prowess while you dance and move across the battlefield seamlessly.
While you're using your Dance ability, your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 10 feet and you can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Danse Macabre
entries: You have mastered the art of dancing on the battlefield. Your very presence inspires even more combatants to transcend their physical limits in combat, making them even deadlier in turn.

The radius of your Dance ability is now 20 feet. When you use your Dance ability, you may empower two allies simultaneously. Both allies must remain inside the 20-foot radius to receive the benefits of your dance. If one leaves while the other one remains in the area of effect, the one remaining still enjoys the benefits, but you must use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} and roll your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die if you wish to empower a second ally again. The new roll overrides the previous one.

For instance: The original {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} roll is 8, and you are inspiring two creatures. One creature leaves the radius of your Dance and loses the benefits of the Dance. A new creature enters the radius and you use your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to roll your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die to inspire that second creature, the result being a 4. Both creatures now add +4 instead of +8 to their ability checks, saving throws, and attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the City
entries: Druids belonging to the Circle of the City go against what most think of when they envision a Druid. Instead of protecting nature by preserving the spaces untouched by civilization, they bring nature to the spaces where people live, and seek to establish a symbiotic relationship between mankind and the natural world. They see villages, towns, and cities as ecosystems in their own right, no different from a forest, jungle, or desert. These Druids forgo the secrecy and reclusiveness that most druidic circles hold dear and sacred, and replace it with what they see as a stronger force better able to enact long-lasting change: community. They are pillars of these communities, establishing and preserving green spaces that not only bring nature into the day-to-day lives of the city's inhabitants, but also double as useful tools for the residents.

The work of the urban Druid is not done in isolated, magical forests, but in parks, community gardens, and city orchards. They are not only concerned with the lives of wolves, bears, and other majestic wild animals, but also the lives of street dogs, abandoned cats, and creatures most see as vermin. Their mission is not to create a space for nature inside of a city, but to erase the line between nature and city completely.

Some Circle of the City Druids remain in one city, making it their life's mission to tend to it like a garden, and becoming a political force in their places of residence; some travel, bringing some of their primal magic to every settlement they visit; and some embark on pilgrimages to abandoned temples, castle ruins, poisonous swamps, and other places where nature has overtaken the living spaces of people, bringing balance to these sites and making them habitable for new people to breathe life into them once more.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Fortress
entries: When you choose this circle at 3rd level, you are able to benefit from mankind's innovations without losing your connection to nature. You gain proficiency with Heavy armor, and are able to don armor and use shields made of metal.

subclassFeature.name: Terrain Tactician
entries: You are able to call on the power of nature and harness its effects. The benefits you gain depend on whether you are standing on “Natural” or “Constructed” terrain. Natural Terrain is any ground that has not been significantly shaped by civilization, such as soil, grass, or snow. Constructed Terrain is the opposite: ground that has been fabricated or shaped by mankind's hands, such as cut stone, metal sheets, or wooden boards. Standing on a rock in the forest would be considered Natural Terrain, whereas standing on stone bricks on a castle's ramparts would be considered Constructed Terrain. Whether a terrain is considered natural or constructed does not depend on if the materials used are “natural” or not, but rather the amount of involvement people had in giving it its current shape. If it is ambiguous, the nature of any given terrain is determined at the GM's discretion.

items: While standing on {@b Natural Terrain}, you harness the healing energy of nature and become attuned to its consciousness:
You gain {@dice 1d4} {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} at the beginning of each turn.
You gain proficiency with the {@skill Perception} skill.
While standing on {@b Constructed Terrain}, you strengthen your body against harmful effects and are able to harness the wisdom of mankind:
You add {@dice 1d6} to all Dexterity saving throws.
You gain proficiency with the {@skill Insight} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Shaper
entries: You can strengthen your pull on the natural energies you gain from your environment. As an action, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid|XPHB|2} feature to strengthen the effects you gain from the terrain you occupy, rather than transforming into a beast form. While this feature is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: While standing on {@b Natural Terrain}, you add your Wisdom modifier to the {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} you gain at the beginning of each turn.

While standing on {@b Constructed Terrain}, choose one damage type between Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Poison. You are now Resistant to that damage type until the start of your next turn, upon which you may choose the same damage Resistance or a different one.

entries: These benefits last for 10 minutes or until you use your Wild Shape ability again.

subclassFeature.name: Land's Spoils
entries: Your influence over the terrain you occupy extends past yourself, allowing you to share the gifts of the land with your allies and encumber those who go against your vision. All terrain within 10 feet of you becomes Difficult Terrain for any creature Hostile to you. Additionally, while your Wild Shaper feature is active, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to choose a creature within 10 feet of you. While that creature is within 10 feet of you, they enjoy the same bonuses you derive from your Terrain Tactician feature (but not your Wild Shaper feature).

subclassFeature.name: Teeming Terrain
entries: Your influence over the environment surrounding you grows, harvesting stronger fruits from its effects. The {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} and bonuses to saving throws given by the Terrain Tactician feature increase: roll {@dice 1d6} instead of a d4 for the {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} gained when standing on Natural Terrain, and roll a {@dice 1d8} instead of a d6 to add to Dexterity saving throws when standing on Constructed Terrain. Additionally, you can choose two creatures within 10 feet of you rather than one to enjoy the same bonuses from your Terrain Tactician feature while your Wild Shaper feature is active.

subclassFeature.name: Terraformer
entries: You are no longer constrained by the terrain you stand on, now able to change its nature to your will. When you expend a use of Wild Shape to gain the benefits of your Wild Shaper feature, you choose whether the terrain within 10 feet of you is considered Natural or Constructed, and transform it to match. For example, wooden floorboards grow vines and roots, or dirt covered in sand and rock turns to a cobblestone road. You can change the terrain around you again at the beginning of each subsequent turn without using an action for as long as your Wild Shaper feature is active.

subclassFeature.name: Scion
entries: Whether because they belong to a long lineage entrusted as stewards of a centuries-old artifact, or because a mysterious relic is thrust upon them by happenstance, a Scion is a Fighter in possession of an extremely powerful weapon.

Scions use a mythic arm: a weapon brimming with magic and, just like the Fighter who wields it, potential. It'd be a mistake to assume that a Scion is only strong because of the weapon they build. To actually access the power of the mythic arm, a Scion must hone not only their technique, but their connection with their weapon.
By strengthening the bond between the two, the Scion becomes the only one able to harness their weapon's true power and unlock its full potential.

subclassFeature.name: Mythic Arm
entries: You wield a mythic arm, an extremely powerful weapon brimming with boundless potential for you to unlock. How you acquired this mythic arm is up to you, but it must be a weapon you are proficient with. When you reach 3rd level, choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Necrotic, Poison, Radiant, or Thunder. All mythic arm attacks made with the additional action granted by your Action Surge deal {@damage 1d8} of your chosen damage along with your weapon damage.

subclassFeature.name: Wielding Legend
entries: The powerful magic that makes your weapon a mythic arm binds it to you and protects it from tampering. Your mythic arm counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to nonmagical attacks and damage and cannot rust, be dulled, or break. You cannot be disarmed while wielding your mythic arm as long as you're not incapacitated.

You can also sense the direction of the mythic arm's location and on which plane of existence it's located. If the arm is moving, you know the direction of its movement. Additionally, your mythic arm can absorb the enchantment and the shape of another weapon. When you acquire an enchanted weapon, you can spend one hour to transfer the enchantment from the enchanted weapon into your mythic arm. For example, if you wield a Longsword as your mythic arm and acquire a +1 Handaxe that has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all attack rolls against Beasts, you can take one hour to transfer that enchantment to your mythic arm, after which it will be a +1 Longsword that has Advantage on all attack rolls against Beasts.

You are also able to change your mythic arm into the shape of any weapon it has previously absorbed an enchantment from by spending one hour concentrating on it. For example, after absorbing the enchantment from the +1 Handaxe of the previous example, you can now turn your mythic arm into a Handaxe by spending one hour concentrating on the mythic arm.
If you do not meet the prerequisites to attune to the weapon, you cannot transfer its enchantment into your mythic arm.
Once you have transferred an enchantment into the mythic arm, the original weapon loses its enchantment.

subclassFeature.name: Wondrous Wielder
entries: You gain further control of your mythic arm, and you can manipulate the way you wield it in battle to transcend the limits of normal weapons. At the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can select one of the following weapon properties to apply to your mythic arm: Finesse, Light, Reach, or Thrown (Range 20/60). The mythic arm retains the weapon property indefinitely, until you use this feature to select a different property.

subclassFeature.name: Unlocked Potential
entries: The bond between you and your mythic arm allows you to draw even more power from your weapon:
The additional damage you deal when making an attack with your mythic arm with the additional action granted by your Action Surge increases to {@damage 2d8}. At 18th level, it becomes {@damage 3d8}.

You choose an additional damage type for your Mythic Arm feature. When you use an Action Surge, you choose which of the available damage types your additional attacks will deal. At 18th level, you can choose one additional damage type.

You can absorb an additional enchantment into your mythic arm. If more than one enchantment includes a bonus to attack and damage rolls, the higher bonus is applied to your mythic arm. At 18th level, you gain the option to absorb yet another additional enchantment, to a total of 3.

subclassFeature.name: Unleash Potential
entries: You gain further control of your mythic arm, allowing you to unlock some of its hidden potential without exerting yourself in the process. On a successful attack, you can deal the additional damage you would deal with your Action Surge attacks. You can use this feature only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Mythic Scion
entries: Your mythic arm has become an extension of yourself, unlocking its full potential. Whenever you make an attack roll with the additional action granted by your Action Surge, you treat all rolls of 9 or lower as a 10, and those attack rolls cannot be made at {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.
Additionally, when you roll for {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} and have no uses of Action Surge remaining, you regain 1 use.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Love
entries: Paladins of Love both exemplify and go against what one thinks of when they envision a Paladin. They are known to be extremely committed to their cause, but what fuels their commitment is not a sense of morality, or a divine sense of justice, but rather their very own feelings. Paladins of Love reject the idea that to be a holy warrior, one must be unfeeling in the commitment of living their life according to an oath. Their oath itself relies on the love that inspires them to swear by the tenets they follow. To them, loving eyes are the only eyes not clouded by superfluous ideals and morals.

Paladins of Love choose a beloved—or rather, their feelings choose for them. A Paladin's beloved, what they love most in this world and all the others, is the source of their power. Most Paladins' beloved are people. Parents gain magical abilities by swearing an oath to love and protect their child, or lovers battle together and use their love for each other as the force that guides their blows. Other Paladins of Love, however, find their beloved in a deity, or a place, or a group of people, or a concept. Paladins of Love are not interested in questions of morality, and are not required to find a beloved that is 'good'—they are only required to love the object(s) of their affection unconditionally.
As long as the Paladin feels an extremely powerful love towards their beloved, they can swear the Oath of Love and become what is commonly referred to as a Knight of Hearts.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Love
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Love hold the feelings of the Paladin as what is most important. Their commitment to protect and cherish what they love, along with their vows, pushes Paladins of Love to feel strongly and proudly.

entries.name: Love Unabashedly
entries: I desecrate what I love by being ashamed of my feelings. I will wear my heart on my sleeve and love proudly.

entries.name: Love my Beloved
entries: Those whom I love and those who love what I love are my beloved, and I will be their sword and their shield.

entries.name: Love is Sacred
entries: If anyone or anything loves strongly, I will respect their affection and their feelings and help their love flourish, no matter how different from my own feelings theirs are.

entries.name: Love Makes us Better
entries: No matter the circumstances, I won't let my love waver, for it strengthens not only me, but also all of my beloved.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: The magic of your oath ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Paladin level specified in the Oath of Love Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Loving Embrace
entries: You can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Paladin|XPHB|3} to uncloud the feelings of a loved one, returning their mind and body to their control. As an action, you touch a creature. The creature is immediately free of any of the following conditions: {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB}, {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, {@condition Petrified|XPHB}, and {@condition Stunned|XPHB}. The creature is also free of any other effects that negate their free will, such as possession.

entries.name: Galvanizing Affection
entries: You can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Paladin|XPHB|3} to channel the strength of your love into an inspiring, rousing cry that empowers your loved ones. As an action, you present your holy symbol and choose a number of willing creatures (that can include you) equal to your Charisma modifier. For 1 minute, these creatures add half of your Charisma modifier, rounded up, to their damage rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Love
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can empower your allies, and especially your beloved, with your love. When a Friendly and willing creature within 10 feet of you makes an attack roll, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to add your Charisma modifier to their attack roll.

Additionally, you can use your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to select a Friendly and willing creature within your aura. This creature is now your beloved, and enjoys a number of bonuses while within your aura:

items: They add your Charisma modifier to one of their attack rolls per round.
They gain a +1 bonus to their {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC}.
They are instantly stabilized if they are reduced to to 0 hit points.

entries: The creature counts as your beloved for 1 minute or until they leave the radius of your aura. At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered by Love
entries: Starting at 15th level, you become stronger when fighting side by side with those you love. When the Friendly and willing creature you have selected within your aura as your beloved is within 10 feet of you, you enjoy the following bonuses:

items: You add a +1 bonus to all your attacks and damage rolls.
You gain a +1 bonus to {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC}.

subclassFeature.name: Knight of Hearts
entries: You become the living embodiment of the love you feel so strongly, which gives you and those you love the following benefits:

items: You can choose a number of Friendly and willing creatures equal to your Charisma modifier as your beloved. They all enjoy the same bonuses while within your aura.
You add a +2 instead of a +1 to your {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC}, along with all your attack rolls and damage rolls, as long as there is a conscious beloved within your aura.

subclassFeature.name: Cowpoke
entries: When we think of a protector of the natural world against those who mistreat it or wish to harm it, when we think of gaining magic through the connection with nature itself, when we think of unlocking the secrets that allow one to not only survive but thrive far from civilization, we rarely think of the Cowpoke, but those who belong to this oft-ignored conclave are Rangers just as prodigious as any other.

The first Cowpoke Rangers did not follow the traditional creation of conclaves; rather, Ranger magic found them. Cowpokes protected their ranches and their cattle. They respected the land and learned its secrets so they could survive. They bonded with their animal companions. And that was enough for the first traces of Ranger magic to manifest in these newborn Rangers. Years of refinement, perfecting, and teaching have made of this emerging Ranger way a true conclave, complete with masters, disciples, and traditions and lessons to follow.

Those who foolishly believe Cowpokes lack the mysticism of other Rangers fail to look at them with eyes unclouded by preconceived notions of what a Ranger can be. Cowpokes hear the whispers of the plains and speak back, they feel the primal emotions that govern the actions of the cattle they tend to, and they know of the deep, unknowable magic that watches expectantly, waiting just at the edge of the light of the campfire.

subclassFeature.name: Cowpoke Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Cowpoke Spells table. The spell counts as a Ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Cowpoke Marksmanship
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with firearms. Additionally, you also gain proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}, allowing you to craft ammunition for any firearm for half the price it costs to buy it. Crafting a set of 10 rounds of ammunition takes 1 hour.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Whisperer
entries: Your expertise and know-how in dealing with animals allows you to create a supernatural bond with any Beast. As an action, you can attempt to befriend a Beast that can see and hear you and is within 30 feet of you. You must make a Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. The DC for this check equals 10 + the CR of the Beast, rounding up.

If the check is successful, the Beast is Friendly to you, trusts you, and will heed some of your commands, within reason. The Beast won't attack your enemies, and it won't engage in any action that will lead to its certain death. The Beast can, among other things, bring you an object out of your reach, carry a message to someone it could reasonably find, indicate the way of a location it knows, scout ahead, or, if its biology permits it, carry you and be used as a mount. If you choose to mount it, the Beast gains +10 feet to its Speed, and you gain a +1 bonus to your weapon and spell attack rolls while you are mounted.

Willingly harming the Beast will make it stop seeing you as a friend, at which point it might turn Hostile, depending on the nature of the Beast in question, at the GM's discretion. The Beast will not leave the general area where it lives by more than 100 feet: for example, befriending an elk that lives in a particular forest means the elk won't follow you anymore once you are 100 feet away from the forest it calls home.

subclassFeature.name: Hot Hand
entries: Your expertise with firearms grows, making you an even more prodigious marksman. The range of all firearms is increased by 10 feet for you, and you ignore the {@itemProperty LD|XPHB|Loading} property of firearms with which you are proficient.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Bull's-Eye
entries: At 11th level, you gain the ability to infuse your bullets with your own magic, allowing you to take a shot so precise it supernaturally tracks its target. When taking the Attack action with a firearm, you can spend one of your spell slots to empower this attack. When you do so, this attack gains a bonus to its attack roll equal to the level of the spell slot used and a bonus to the damage roll equal to three times the level of the spell slot used. The attack also ignores any bonuses from {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Half Cover}, and is not made at {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} when firing at long range or against an enemy within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Quick Draw
entries: Spellcasting and shooting have become so natural to you that you are able to weave one with the other seamlessly. When you make a ranged weapon attack using a firearm against one creature, you can cast one spell you know as part of the same action. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier. You regain all uses of this ability after finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Familiarist
entries: Wizards who focus their arcane studies on the art of familiar summoning are referred to by many names, the most common being 'Familiarists' or 'daemoners'. What distinguishes them from general summoners is their extreme focus on familiars specifically, and the combat applications that these summoned spirits bring to the battlefield.

Familiarists push the boundaries of what a familiar can do for a Wizard, elevating them beyond the basic role of helper and making them an integral part of the Wizard's arcane practice. When in battle, the two move in perfect synchronicity to bring an onslaught of arcane and martial damage down upon their enemies.

There are accounts of master Familiarists who cultivate a bond with their familiar so deep that the edges between the two blur until becoming indistinguishable, while others hone their craft to a point where familiar and Wizard form not a duo but an army in and of themselves. No familiar is more of a partner and comrade-in-arms to its wizard than the enhanced familiar of a Familiarist.

subclassFeature.name: Enhanced Familiar
entries: Your familiarity with the arcane art of summoning familiars allows you to call forth a spirit in a form stronger than that of your fellow Wizards' familiars.

You know the {@spell Find Familiar} spell, you always have it prepared, and it does not count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. You can cast Find Familiar with a casting time of one action a number of times per day equal to your Intelligence modifier. When you do so, you do not consume any material components in the casting of the spell, and the familiar you summon uses a different stat block and has abilities—outlined in this arcane tradition—that are not normally granted by the Find Familiar spell.

When you summon your Enhanced Familiar, you choose which abilities it has by selecting one of the available stat blocks. See the game statistics in the Enhanced Familiar stat blocks below, which use your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} (PB) in several places. Your Enhanced Familiar takes the form of an animal, though with some telltale sign of its arcane nature. What kind of animal form it takes depends on which Enhanced Familiar stat block you choose. For example, choosing the {@creature Enhanced Familiar (Flying)|PointyHatArcaneCodex} stat block makes your Enhanced Familiar capable of flight, so it may take the form of an owl whose feathers sport the pattern of a shifting star map, or a great moth with the phases of the moon stamped on its wings.

In combat, your Enhanced Familiar shares your {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count, but takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the Dodge action, unless you take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on your turn to command the familiar to take a different action. The stat block chosen dictates which actions the Enhanced Familiar can take. If you're incapacitated, the Enhanced Familiar can take any action of its choice, not just Dodge.

If your Enhanced Familiar is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it disappears. You can cast the spell Find Familiar using this feature to summon it again. Whenever you cast the Find Familiar spell using this feature, you can choose to summon your Enhanced Familiar using a different Enhanced Familiar stat block.
You regain all uses of this feature at the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Familiar
entries: The arcane connection between you and your Enhanced Familiar allows you to use it as an extension of yourself in your own spellcasting. You can cast spells as though you were in the Enhanced Familiar's space, but you must use your own senses.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Familiar
entries: You and your Enhanced Familiar have become a deadly duo in battle.
Whenever you use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to command your Enhanced Familiar to make a melee attack as an action, it can attack twice, rather than once.
Additionally, your Enhanced Familiar can use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} whenever it is within 5 feet of you or a creature attacking you to become the target of an attack targeting you.

subclassFeature.name: Hero Familiar
entries: The bond between you and your Enhanced Familiar is so strong that your very lives are bound together.

When your current Hit Point total is reduced to 0, your Enhanced Familiar can spend its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to drop its own HP to 0 instead. However many Hit Points it had whenever it takes this Reaction are immediately passed on to you.
Once your Enhanced Familiar has taken this Reaction, it cannot do so again until you finish a Long Rest.

subclassFeature.name: Exalted Familiar
entries: At 14th level, you and your Enhanced Familiar have become as one, allowing it to use your own arcane power to become an even more threatening force in battle.

Whenever you cast a leveled spell that deals damage, your Enhanced Familiar can add an additional {@damage 1d8} damage to its attacks until the end of its next turn. The type of damage dealt is the same as the damage dealt by your spell.

Your familiar gains a +1 bonus to its {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC}. Whenever it makes a saving throw, the familiar may choose to use either its own ability score bonuses and proficiencies or yours. Whenever your Enhanced Familiar uses its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to become the target of an attack targeting you, it can immediately make an attack against the creature targeting you as part of the same Reaction, provided said creature is within range of the Enhanced Familiar's attack.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4 to 7 feet tall) or Small (about 3 to 4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Arcane Imprint
entries: Magic has left an indelible mark on you. Choose the school of magic from the Arcane Imprints table. Your choice affects the benefits you gain from your Arcane Boon and Spellbound traits as well as your appearance.

items.name: Abjuration
entries: At the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can choose to gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage. You retain that Resistance until the end of the next Long Rest. Additionally, you gain a +1 bonus to your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC}.

items.name: Conjuration
entries: You manifest arcane echoes of your own arms around you. These arms are not affected if you are Grappled, and can manipulate a tiny object, wield a weapon that has the Light property, hold a Shield, or perform Somatic components of spells.

entries.name: Familiar Form
entries: Like any familiar, your body can change into the form of a different animal you choose. You have a number of Familiar Points equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. At the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you may spend these points to choose from the Familiar Traits outlined in the table on the next page.

Once you've chosen your Familiar Traits at the end of a Long Rest, you can choose the animal that best fits that specific combination. Choosing Flight and Mimicry might lead you to take the form of a raven; choosing Swim and Burrow might make you take the form of a giant salamander; and choosing Keen Smell, Keen Hearing, and Nimble could mean you take the form of a hound.

entries: TIP: In a fantasy world, “mundane” animals can be as different from ours as you and your GM want them to be. Maybe in this world there is a species of octopus that can walk on land with as much dexterity as it can swim in water, and can not only mimic the textures and colors that surround it but also the sounds it hears, leading you to pick Amphibious, Camouflage, Mimicry, and Swim as your Familiar Traits for the day. Talk to your GM to come up with interesting options to accommodate your Familiar Form.

entries.name: Familiar Connection
entries: You can speak telepathically to any creature you can see within 60 feet of you. Your telepathic utterances are in a language you know, and the creature understands you only if it knows that language. The creature can respond to you telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through the eyes of the creature you're communicating telepathically with and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, as long as that creature is Friendly to you. When you do so, you gain the benefits of any special senses that the creature has. During this time, you are {@condition Deafened} and {@condition Blinded} with regard to your own senses.

entries.name: Familiar Hand
entries: The inherent magic that makes you a familiar allows you to manifest your own version of the arcanist's trusty {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB}. Two spectral hands float around you, resembling the hands of whoever first summoned you. These hands cannot move outside of the space you're occupying, meaning that your range when holding a weapon with them is the one stipulated for the weapon you're holding, but you can choose to make them visible or invisible without using an action, and you can control them as if they were your own.

You can interact with any object, including weapons, using these hands. When you do so, you cannot interact with an additional object using any of your limbs; for example, if you are wielding a Shortsword in one floating hand and a Shield in another, you cannot then carry a second sword in your mouth, paw, or tentacle and gain the benefits of Dual Wielding while bearing a Shield. The hands use your own ability scores when making any checks or determining their carrying capacity.

entries.name: Form Fitting Function
entries: You are able to use some of your form-changing familiar magic to affect your own equipment in order to best suit your ever-changing frame. Once you don any armor, it is magically altered to fit your current Familiar Form. For example, donning a full suit of Plate Armor as a squirrel will result in the suit morphing to best fit your current squirrel body.

entries.name: Starting Point
entries: You can choose to keep certain elements of another species when picking Augmented as your species:  any skill proficiencies you gained from it and any Climb, Fly, or Swim speed you gained from it.
If you choose to not keep those elements, you instead gain proficiency in two skills of your choice.

entries.name: Tinkerer
entries: The routine upkeep of your augmentation has made you particularly proficient in the use of the necessary tools required to maintain your magical prosthetic. Your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} is doubled when making checks with {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}.

entries.name: Patching Up
entries: Your augmentation is magically connected to your own body and, therefore, your life force. As an action, you can make an ability check using your {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} on your augmentation. The DC is equal to 15 if your current HP is equal to or above half of your Hit Point maximum (rounding down), or 18 if your current HP is below half of your Hit Point maximum. On a success, you gain a number of Hit Points equal to {@dice 1d4} plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Augmentation
entries: Your body has been outfitted with a magical artificial augmentation that you can use in a variety of ways, depending on the specific augmentation. Choose one of the following augmentations when choosing this species.

entries.name: Utility Augmentation
items: This magical augmentation grants you utility capabilities that far surpass those of the original body part you have replaced.

You gain Expertise in one skill and with one tool of your choice. Your Proficiency Bonus is doubled when making checks with that tool. The tool is embedded into or otherwise affixed to your augmentation and cannot be dropped unless you are somehow parted with your augmentation.

items.name: Enhanced Augmentation
entries: At 10th level, provided you have access to a master craftsman specializing in magical augmentations and 500 GP to pay for their services, you can choose an additional skill and tool to gain Expertise in. It takes {@dice 1d4} days for the master craftsman to outfit your augmentation with its new capabilities, during which you do not gain the advantages that your augmentation grants you.
Examples of this augmentation include:

items: An artificial eye that grants you Expertise with {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB} and in the {@skill Perception} skill.
A set of magically-enhanced mechanical hands that grants you Expertise with {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB} and in the {@skill Sleight of Hand} skill.
A clockwork voice box that grants you Expertise with one musical instrument and in the {@skill Performance} skill.

entries.name: Combat Augmentation
items: This magical augmentation grants you combat capabilities that allow you to use your augmentation as a weapon.

Your {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC} increases by 1, and a weapon with which you are proficient is fitted into your augmentation. Attacks made with this weapon can deal your choice of Force damage or its normal damage type, you can use the {@variantrule Weapon Mastery Properties|XPHB|mastery property} of this weapon, and the weapon cannot be dropped. You can change this weapon by spending 1 hour fitting the new weapon to your augmentation and 30 gold pieces for new parts.

items.name: Enhanced Augmentation
entries: At 10th level, provided you have access to a master craftsman specializing in magical augmentations and 500 GP to pay for their services, you can fit your augmentation with an additional weapon with which you are proficient. Your {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB|AC} increases by 1 again, to a total of +2, and you are able to stow one weapon inside your augmentation and draw the other weapon during your turn without the use of an action. This new weapon has the same capabilities as the first weapon attached to your augmentation.
Examples of this augmentation include:

items: A mechanical arm outfitted with a blade that comes out between the knuckles of your hand augmentation.
A crossbow inlaid into your forearm.
An artificial hand attached to your arm by a chain, allowing you to use it as a {@item Flail|XPHB}.

entries.name: Movement Augmentation
items: This magical augmentation enhances your movement, allowing you to move faster, even through hard-to-navigate terrain.
Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 5 feet. Additionally, moving through nonmagical {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} does not cost you extra movement.

items.name: Enhanced Augmentation
entries: At 10th level, provided you have access to a master craftsman specializing in magical augmentations and 500 GP to pay for their services, you can enhance your augmentation to grant you even faster movement and additional traversal abilities. Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 5 feet, bringing the total increase to 10 feet. Additionally, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces without falling during the move.
Examples of this augmentation include:

items: A set of mechanical hydraulic-powered legs.
A seat that hovers 5 inches above the ground.
A set of artificial calves with magically-powered jets of energy.

entries.name: Jinx
entries: You are naturally unlucky, which affects you and anyone around you, friend or foe. At the end of each {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, the GM rolls a {@dice d100} on the table below to find out the effects of your bad luck. If the GM feels like the effect rolled is unlikely to happen within that day, they roll again. The GM then selects who or what is the target of your bad luck, and when the effect takes place. The effects of your bad luck can affect any creature (including you) or object within 100 feet of you. The GM should evenly distribute the effects of your bad luck between you, your party, NPCs, and enemies within that 100-foot radius.

Once the effect has taken place, you gain the ability to impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on any {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, even those related to abilities or effects you are not aware of, provided the creature making the roll is within 100 feet of you. Once you've imposed this Disadvantage, the GM rolls on the table again, and so on.
At the end of a Long Rest, any effects that have not yet taken place, including your ability to impose Disadvantage, are discarded and the GM rolls on the table again.

raceFluff.name: Arcaneborn
entries: The most common of the arcaneborn are the elemental plane-touched, but arcanists don't call them by this name. In academic circles that study the arcane, these are referred to instead as “evocation-born.” It is most common for those touched by planar influence to be born of evocation magic, due to the influence of the elemental planes and the meddling of genies in mortal lives. However, it is very much possible—albeit rarer—for them to be born of different schools of magic.

The birth of an arcaneborn not tied to a specific element is much rarer because it can only happen due to prolonged exposure to what is commonly referred as “grand magic.” Magic that changes the fabric of reality, magic that bends the Weave with such force that the ripples it leaves behind influence the lives of those close to the casting for generations; spells that mages would categorize as 9th level or above.

Just like some evocation-born present with glowing lines that pulse with evocation magic, other arcaneborn can be marked by the magic that created them. Because arcaneborn are born from exposure to grand magic, though, these lines manifest instead as the formulae of the spell that made them arcaneborn in the first place. Their skin glows with the text of the spell in question or the magic circles and runes that were used during the casting process. Some arcaneborn have been used as living spell scrolls because of this feature, becoming guardians of specific spells and testing wizards who wish to learn the magic that shines through their skin.

Arcaneborn are also affected by the components used to cast the spells. Somatic components can manifest in the arms, hands, and even feet of the arcaneborn, giving them an eerie arcane glow; verbal components grant the plane-touched an unearthly, magical voice; and material components might even manifest as arcane echoes around the arcaneborn. An arcaneborn born of a spell that used flowers in its casting might manifest those same flowers around themselves as a reflection of the spell that made them an arcaneborn.
The different arcaneborn that are born from the casting of this spell are aligned to the school of magic of the spell that was cast.

raceFluff.name: Ancient Dwarf
entries: The legends are true: dwarves are made of stone. Or rather, they once were. They were extracted from the earth from precious stones and molded into their shape by the gods who lovingly gave them sentience. But the shape they molded dwarves into significantly differs from the one we know today.

Dwarves in the past were made of stone or metal, and this led to two distinct appearances. Those who could trace their lineage to stone had skin that shone like minerals and was veined like marble, and the gemstone used in their creation grew on their heads like hair. Those who were instead born from metal had a metallic luster and shine to their skin, and molten metal flowed from their scalp and their lower jaw instead of hair.

At this stage of dwarven history, dwarves mined not for crafting, but for reproduction. They found gemstones and infused them with magic so that they would one day grow into another dwarf. And the magic they used was none other than arcane magic. The dwarves once worshipped a dwarven deity of the arcane, but also of fertility, since this was how they reproduced. This god was a motherly figure, to contrast Dwarven God's paternal place in the pantheon, and the arcane was associated not only with knowledge but child-rearing.

It was through this deity's guidance that the dwarves mastered the art of the arcane, and then turned it from an art to a science. At this point in time, magic practitioners could only ask the Weave to do as they wanted. The dwarves, on the other hand, made the Weave do what they wanted. They were crafters like the dwarves of today, but crafters of spells; they were the first to jot down formulas and measure arcane components to record the first spells. And they used what was most at hand to craft their spells: the gemstones and metals that made up their own bodies. They chiseled the gems of their beards and poured the metal of their hair, and with those ingredients, they made magic. Under the guiding hand of their arcane god, they became the first arcane experts.

And then, this deity vanished. There is a gap in the records of the dwarves. A gap wide enough to have made them forget they were even born of the stone. Their previous appearance and way of life was sundered, erased along with this mysterious deity and their even more mysterious death.

Whatever the reason for their disappearance, something had severed the connection between dwarves and the arcane completely. No longer able to harvest magic components from their own bodies and with no divine guidance to practice magic—not even able to remember that they once did—one might think dwarves would simply forget spellcraft and the arcane.

But the industrious spirit is stronger than the hardest stone. Dwarves turned back to mining, not for child-rearing but to find the gemstones and metals they once came from; to follow the spells they had once written themselves, despite not remembering doing so. Where once they had crafted spells, dwarves now learned to craft artefacts. In time, over centuries, the dwarves found their own way to the arcane again.

Nowadays, few dwarven scholars even believe the dubious theory that dwarves come from stone, and even fewer of them believe that dwarves were once metallic or stone-like in appearance. But the newly found arcane connection that the dwarves have forged has awakened something within them. There are talks of dwarves born of wizard parents who sport gems on their heads and beards, or molten metal as hair. There are even rumours of clans of ancient dwarves who still have the appearance that all dwarves once did, encased in the stone, dormant. Preserved like veins of precious metals and gems, ready for their brethren to mine deeper and liberate them from their earthen prison, so that they may tell the story of what exactly happened to the dwarven people.

raceFluff.name: Awakened Familiar
entries: Familiars are summoned servants capable of changing forms to best suit the needs of the mage that summoned them. Awakened familiars enjoy these same abilities, except they are no longer bound to anyone's service.

The phenomenon known as "awakening" can affect a familiar for a number of reasons. There have been reports of familiars awakening after centuries of service to one master, the residual magic of countless summonings and various other spells building up to become the familiar's own magical power. Awakenings have also been reported after a familiar has suffered prolonged abuse from its master, finally finding the strength to rebel against them and sever the connection between summoned creature and summoner. There have even been cases where a familiar has awakened after the death of its master, being so paradoxically devoted to them that the familiar liberated itself from the summoning spell that bound it to the arcanist in order to find a way to bring its master back to life.

Whatever the reason for this process, an awakened familiar is no longer a summoned spirit bound to the will of the mage who summoned it. No longer does the familiar have to answer the commands of the one that brought it to this plane; instead, the familiar is now in complete control of its own destiny — or rather, their own destiny. What they do with their newly found free will after awakening is for the awakened familiar to decide.

raceFluff.name: Augmented
entries: Those who choose to become augmented are anything but a monolith. Most augmented become so because they are missing a limb or the capability to hear, see, walk, or even speak. Faced with the challenges that naturally come from their situation, they reach out to master crafters: Artificers who specialize in making and installing wondrous magical prosthetics in a living, humanoid body.

These Artificers take incredible pride in their work, and each add a unique, personal touch to their craft. As a result, no two augmentations look or work the same. They are personally made for the person augmented with them.

Most of the time, a lost arm is replaced with an artificial limb, meant to work exactly like an arm would, but Artificers are inventive by nature, and so many augmented are given secondary characteristics to their augmentations — not just allowing them to replace their lost limb or sense, but also giving them new, additional capabilities.

Some augmented outfit their augmentations with combat capabilities, incorporating finely-tuned weapons into them. Some use incredibly powerful legs or high-tech seats that allow them to move through the battlefield even faster than before, and some add tools to their augmentations, opening up a myriad of possibilities, from integrated musical instruments to perfectly concealed Thieves' Tools.

There are also some who decide to become augmented not after the loss of a sense or limb, but because of the incredible capabilities that their augmentations would grant them. There are assassin clans that augment their members, making them even deadlier at their sinister craft. There are racers who choose to undergo augmentation to participate in the fastest ever races involving living people. There are even whispers of truly heinous master craftsmen, Artificers who force their unethical augmentations on unwilling subjects. Regardless of why and how someone becomes augmented, they all share in common one thing: their augmentations are all as different and unique as the people attached to them.

raceFluff.name: Felis
entries: The felis are people who have been selected to receive the ultimate blessing from the god who rules over the lives of cats.

Nobody knows how exactly this selection happens. It is said that felis are born to those who have greatly impacted the lives of cats for the better, that being felis is a blessing from the god of cats himself to thank them for their help. There are also cases where a person who cared for a feline and defended it from harm has a brush with death; they miraculously survive, but they are changed into one of the felis, their new form a reminder of how the god spared their very life as thanks. There are even tales of people who were awful to cats and turned into felis as a punishment, forced to be what they despise most. Nowadays, however, most felis are just born from the union of two felis parents.

In the same way that their furrier cousins receive a feline trait from the cat deity, the felis receive feline aspects to their appearance. Most often, their ancestry manifests as feline ears like those of a house cat or a lynx; a feline tail; a cat's nose; sharp, claw-like nails; whiskers; or a combination of those. Felis believe that the more cat traits one has, the more they are favored by their god.

There's a distinct culture in felis communities: they are intensely self-reliant. It's seen as greatly shameful for a felis to depend on anyone but themselves, and felis children leave the nest extremely early in order to make their own luck in the world. It's not out of the ordinary to see a felis teen already tending to their own shop or embarking on an adventure. This cultural push to be independent can make others see them as individualistic, even selfish, but those who form a bond with a felis quickly understand that they enjoy companionship just as much as anyone else—they just have their own way of showing it. Their need to be self-reliant does not mean that felis don't help each other; quite the opposite. Many cities have wide felis networks that they use to help each other flourish.

Felis share with their more cat-like cousins their love of stories, but they use them in a different way. Felis culture is shared orally, passing down their history through songs, rhymes, and parables. This cultural appreciation of song, and the way that music is treated as a way to teach history, often makes felis choose the path of the bard, becoming traveling minstrels who share felis tales and songs.

They are often hired to play and sing in the drawing rooms of nobles, where their songs are seen as exotic and strange. It's said that felis presence in noble houses has given birth to a wide network of spies who share coded messages between members through their own version of thieves' cant in the form of song. Some of these felis spies allegedly even double as assassins if this secret organization requires it of them.

The cultural push towards self-reliance, their love for stories, and their innate curiosity often push the felis towards a life of adventuring. Many of them believe that in doing so, they are following in the footsteps of their traveling god, and hope to cross paths with him one day.

raceFluff.name: Jinx
entries: Nobody knows what jinxes did to deserve their fate. Some say that they descend from a halfling who broke all laws of hospitality and was forever cursed by the divine mother of all halflings. Some believe that they were created to make up for the lucky halflings, so that the cosmic scale of fate remains in balance. Whatever the case may be, the reality is that jinxes naturally attract misfortune wherever they go.

It matters little what a jinx does to try to offset their fate; they are constantly followed by a streak of bad luck. A jinx attending any function will ensure that it will rain that day; a wagon will mysteriously break down if a jinx is traveling on it; hosting a jinx in your home will lead to rats finding their way into your pantry and a leak developing in your roof.

The jinx's distinctive looks make it easy for them to be spotted and, sadly, shunned. They stand around three feet tall, like other halflings, but that's where the similarities end. Their skin and hair come only in shades of gray, black, or stark white, as if color had been sapped from them along with their luck. The dark rings around their eyes seem to be indelible, no matter how much sleep they get, and the tips of their fingers are always slightly darker than the rest of their skin, as if their bad luck has tainted them. Most jinxes are born to halfling parents, seemingly at random. The birth of a jinx seems to be, as their entire life all too often is, at the hands of luck.

Faced with this unfortunate existence, jinxes go through life in many different ways. Since many are nomadic by necessity, they take on adventuring, as it's one of the few professions that can benefit from bad luck - after all, the jinx's misfortune can just as easily affect those the jinx is fighting. Some jinxes decide to rebel against their cruel fate, and try to find a way to free themselves and their brethren from their curse in their travels, keeping a happy and positive attitude even in the face of constant misfortune, while others embrace their bad luck and form guilds that send jinxes against their targets to plague them with ill fortune.

entries.name: A Note on Playing the Jinx
entries: Because the jinx's trademark feature can affect other party members, it's very important that you talk not only with your GM but also with the other players before you choose to play a character of this species.

I firmly believe that characters with setbacks and negative features can facilitate incredible moments while in play, but this only works when everyone accepts and is willing to play with those setbacks.

There is an alternate rule that will limit the effects of the jinx's trademark feature. As the system is written, bad luck affects anyone around the jinx somewhat evenly: sometimes the jinx, sometimes their party members, and sometimes NPCs and enemies. Instead, you can choose to only allow yourself and NPCs to be affected by the bad luck, not the other player characters. This means that more unlucky events will be directed at you, but it is a compromise you may be interested in making if your fellow players don't want to use the rules of the jinx's features.

raceFluff.name: Verdant Orc
entries: Verdant orcs are orcs intrinsically con- nected to their original creator deity. When he was sundered, the Orc Father lost his essence, turning him into a god-like monster, but part of his original self keeps fighting within the monster, and this is the part that reached out to his children and created verdant orcs.

Verdant orcs are what orcs were meant to be at their creation. They have an intrinsic connection not only to their creator, but also to nature. They retain the green tint to their skin that gives them their name, but their connection to nature is not just skin deep. Verdant orcs can literally sustain themselves through photosynthesis like a plant, and their connection to their creator god allows them to be creators themselves, excelling in all tasks that require equal knowledge and control of nature and civilization, such as farming or woodworking.

To assume their natural connection or their crafting abilities makes verdant orcs less fearsome warriors than their other orcish siblings would be a mistake, as they retain the powerful bodies characteristic of the orc species. Verdant orcs excel at combat, both in all-out brawls and covert ambushes in their forests. Their connection to their divine Father enhances their resilience, allowing them to gain a surge of energy when pushed to the brink of death.

Verdant orc communities tend to live in the forest, where they thrive, but many leave these bastions of nature. Some do so for personal reasons, but many others go on a quest larger than themselves. Many verdant orcs believe that their Father can be saved and restored to his former self, and it falls to them, those who have received the blessing that was once afforded to all orcs, to save their creator.

headerEntries: The chest weasel casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks):

trait.name: Airtight Seal
entries: The chest weasel doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Cracked Shell
entries: The first time the chest weasel is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it drops to 1 Hit Point instead. Until the end of its next turn, all attacks against the chest weasel have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} and its movement does not provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}. The chest weasel can't use this feature again until it finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

trait.name: False Appearance (While Possessing an Object)
entries: While the chest weasel remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary object.

trait.name: New Home
entries: If the chest weasel possesses a new object, it regains half its total HP.

trait.name: Object Manipulation
entries: While the chest weasel is possessing an object, the object becomes an extension of itself. It can make the object move as fast as the chest weasel can itself move, and it can change characteristics of the object, such as the material from which it's made, its weight (with a maximum weight of 100 pounds and a minimum weight of 10), and its size (making it grow or shrink up to twice its original size).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chest weasel makes two {@i Claw} attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Object Possession
entries: The chest weasel possesses a nonmagical object that isn't currently being worn or carried by a creature within 5 feet of it.

reaction.name: Misty Step
entries: The chest weasel can use {@spell Misty Step|XPHB} after another creature takes any action, without consuming the use of a spell.

trait.name: Distortion Cone
entries: The mind's eye's central eye creates a reality-bending area in a 100-foot Cone. At the start of each of its turns, the mind's eye decides which way the Cone faces, whether the Cone is active, and which one of its three possible effects is active:

items: The ground and any other surfaces within the Cone become magical {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.
Any creature starting its turn within the Cone takes {@damage 1d12} Psychic damage.
All creatures and objects within the cone are in an area of reversed gravity, as in the {@spell Reverse Gravity|XPHB} spell.

trait.name: Watchful Eyes
entries: The mind's eye has Advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

action.name: Eye Rays
entries: The mind's eye shoots two of the following magical rays, choosing one to two targets it can see within 120 feet of it, including itself (roll {@dice 1d6}; reroll if the mind's eye has already used that ray during this turn):

items.name: 1: Perfecting Ray
entries: The targeted creature gains a +1 bonus to all its melee or spell attacks, as well as its damage rolls. The target loses this benefit when this eye ray is used again.

items.name: 2: Healing Ray
entries: The targeted creature regains a number of Hit Points equal to {@dice 2d8 + 4}.

items.name: 3: Mending Ray
entries: The targeted creature is freed from any or all of the following conditions: {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, {@condition Petrified|XPHB}, {@condition Poisoned|XPHB}, and {@condition Stunned|XPHB}.

items.name: 4: Enlarging/Reducing Ray
entries: {@actSave con}: {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} The creature is under the effect of the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce|XPHB} spell. The mind's eye chooses whether the targeted creature is enlarged or reduced. The target can choose to fail this saving throw.

items.name: 5: Destroying Ray
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} 20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) Psychic damage.

items.name: 6: Ruining Ray
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} The target takes a −1 penalty to all its melee or spell attack rolls, as well as its damage rolls. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Create Wall
entries: The mind's eye creates a wall made of the same material as the ground the wall stands on. The mind's eye can only create this wall within its Distortion Cone. The wall can measure up to 8 feet in height, 20 feet in length, and 1 foot in width. The wall cannot be interrupted: the mind's eye cannot create a small 5-foot wall and a longer 15-foot wall that aren't connected. It can, however, create a wall in an L shape or another complex shape. If the wall is created in a space occupied by a creature, the creature is pushed to the nearest unoccupied space and takes 1d8 Force damage.

legendary.name: Eye Ray
entries: The mind's eye uses one of its Eye Rays.

legendary.name: Shifting Glance
entries: The mind's eye changes where its central eye is facing, changing the position of its distortion cone.

legendary.name: Hasty Remodeling
entries: The mind's eye uses its Create Wall action.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The shubeik casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks):

trait.name: Incorporeal Form
entries: The shubeik can occupy the space of any creature, regardless of its size.

trait.name: Shubeik Wish
entries: The shubeik can grant 3 wishes per day, only one wish per creature per day. The shubeik cannot be compelled through any magical means to grant a wish. A creature has to make a wish for a shubeik to be able to grant it, but a creature does not have to speak its wish aloud for the shubeik to be able to grant said wish. The thought of the wish is enough for the shubeik to be able to manifest it into reality. The shubeik can hear and understand the wishes that any creature within 100 feet of the shubeik thinks of. {@variantrule Rules on Genie Wishes|PointyHatArcaneCodex|A shubeik's wish is subject to all rules that govern genie wishes.}

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shubeik makes two {@i Dagger} attacks or uses its {@i Smoke Tendril} twice.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) Slashing damage plus 7 {@damage 2d6} Radiant or Fire damage (shubeik's choice).

action.name: Smoke Tendril
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) Radiant or Fire damage (shubeik's choice). On a hit, the creature is subjected to the following effect. {@actSave con} {@dc 17}. {@actSaveFail} The target gains the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until the end of the shubeik's next turn.

action.name: Let There be Light
entries: The shubeik assumes a glowing form of bright smoke. For 1 minute, it can move without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}, it has Advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) checks, and dispels any curse or hallowed terrain within 30 feet of it. If the shubeik attacks any creature or casts a spell, it assumes its regular form instantaneously. The shubeik can assume its regular form at will, without using an action.

action.name: Shubeik Wish (3/Day)
entries: The shubeik grants the wish of a creature within 100 feet.

monsterFluff.name: Un-Familiar
entries: Reports of the creation of an un-familiar are few and far between, but they are all marked by tragedy. The precise process to create an un-familiar is not known, but arcanists have gleaned common links between the different instances of un-familiars being born. Many un-familiars seem to be born at the time of familiar summoning. Interruption of the casting ritual, faulty or corrupted materials being used in the casting process, or even interference by an arcanist with ill intent during the familiar summoning have been known to create an un-familiar.

More upsettingly, mistreatment or neglect of a familiar by its master has also been known to cause the birth of an un-familiar. Wizards who leave their familiar in its pocket dimension for inordinately long periods of time have reported summoning an un-familiar instead of their familiar when they finally decide to call it back, to nefarious consequences. There's even a well-known case of a Warlock repeatedly ordering their familiar to perform tasks the familiar did not approve of. The familiar gradually lost control of its form until it finally formed into an un-familiar.

Whatever the reason behind their creation, un-familiars are extremely dangerous aberrations. Their form is more arcane than physical, their body almost entirely composed of raw magic. The un-familiar's form is therefore ever-changing, manifesting body parts of different animals in the blink of an eye according to its needs. An un-familiar can sprout wings to fly high one second and then plunge into a body of water and swim with its new-formed fins the next, making it extremely hard to pin down. This roiling arcane energy at the heart of the un-familiar's form also allows it to cast spells, but the chaotic nature of its existence makes it unable to control this magic, slingling spells its master once knew at its enemies and, most commonly, at its former master.

Un-familiars seem to have a searing hatred for arcane spellcasters—and, more particularly, their former masters, or any caster with their own familiar. Spellcasters that have faced an un-familiar along with their own familiar report theirs being particularly shaken by the experience, with some witnessing the summoned spirit struggle to maintain its form after seeing the un-familiar. If the un-familiar condition is somehow contagious amongst familiars, this makes them an even more terrifying foe than was previously thought.

monsterFluff.name: Chest Weasel
entries: Hags are known to feed on suffering, although there are stories of hags that feed on other emotions, like ambition, or fear—but they are not the only fey beings that feed on emotions. Chest weasels feed on frustration.

These fey beings derive sustenance from annoying those around them, and they do so through their ability to possess objects and bend them to their will. A chest weasel will inhabit any object it thinks it can use to create delectable frustration. When they are young, many chest weasels live in cities, possessing small objects like stones in a cobblestone street, which they raise as people walk by to trip them. When chest weasels reach maturity, they develop a taste for a more sophisticated frustration, which is where they get their name.

Chest weasels find that adventurers going through deadly dungeons have very low tolerance for any sort of shenanigans, which means that frustration is bubbling right below the surface, and they just need a push for it to come spewing out. The weasels possess chests, or other containers that an adventurer might look into in search of treasure, and make it their mission to annoy them as much as possible.

They make a lockbox incorporeal, or shift the position of a jar so that adventurers are unable to actually inspect it, or make it so that a chest produces another chest when opened, feasting all the while on the adventurers' irritation.

But despite what their behavior might lead you to believe, chest weasels are not inherently evil, and many understand that their source of food is not a pleasant experience for those who supply it. If properly satiated, a chest weasel will pop out of its container and thank the adventurer who has fed it, either by giving them whatever was hidden away in its container, or by helping the adventurer in their trek through the dungeon.
There are even stories of chest weasels striking deals with magic shop owners, or becoming shop owners themselves, so that they may better cater to those they plan on feeding from later.

monsterFluff.name: Mind's Eye
entries: A mind's eye is what happens when an aberration that believes itself to be perfect becomes aware of its flaws. The circumstances that trigger this realization don't matter; once the seed of doubt is planted in the aberration's mind, they spiral into a deep pit of self-doubt. What pulls them out of that pit is a new motivation: to be perfect.

The mind's eye must be as perfect as they see themselves to be. It's this impossible drive that allows them to unlock an ability that all the aberrations the mind's eye is derived from have, quite literally, dormant within themselves: their ability to warp reality.

This specific original aberration is only able to achieve this within dreams, and has no control over it, whereas a mind's eye can do this at will, and so they continually transform themselves and their surroundings in their quest towards perfection. Over the course of their process to become perfect, a mind's eye becomes almost unrecognizable as their original self. They keep their central eye and the eyes on their eyestalks, but their flesh is changed into perfect, polished metal. They get rid of any biological matter, becoming fully artificial, unaging.

However, the process never ends. The mind's eye is aware that they aren't perfect, but their egotistical nature doesn't allow them to understand that they never will be. They constantly change themselves and, soon enough, they turn their eyes outwards as well as inwards. They realize their lair is not perfect, nor are their minions, and they go about changing them, too, using the same reality-warping power that they used to change themselves. Mind's eyes are often referred to as “Architects” because of the magnificent lairs they build in their never-ending quest for perfection.

monsterFluff.name: Shubeik
entries: Shubeiks and lubeiks are genies that are born out of a soul melding with the cosmic energies of good or evil rather than with the primal energies of the elements, and this dichotomy makes them both similar to and polar opposites of one another.
Unlike most genies, both shubeiks and lubeiks spend most of their time on the Material Plane, as that is where they believe they can carry out their work most effectively.

Shubeiks, genies of good, only grant wishes to evil people. They seek out the greediest, most violent, most selfish mortals and put themselves in their service. The trick is that shubeiks are more likely than any other genie to twist the wording of a wish against the wisher. Shubeiks will take the wishes of their evil masters and twist them to generate more good in the world, showing their masters that they can make the people and the world around them better. They do this in the hope of changing their masters' minds so that, in time, the person might forgo their evil ways—and perhaps even join them in death as a new shubeik.

Shubeiks might be the embodiment of good, but they are not naive. If the person they are accompanying fails to see the error of their ways after receiving the help of a shubeik, the genie will turn against their “master,” angered by their dogged refusal to become a better person.

Lubeiks, genies of evil, grant poisoned wishes to good people. Much like shubeiks, they'll attach themselves to a mortal, but they'll choose those who possess truly kind souls, and then they'll wait for their target to slip up. For them to have an unkind thought, a selfish thought. And then they make that thought a wish, and that wish a reality. Every mortal, no matter how kind, selfless, or gentle, has felt envy, or wished ill on someone they despise, and a lubeik will wait in the darkness for those thoughts to bubble up to the surface. They try to steer a good soul towards evil and, hopefully upon their death, give rise to a new lubeik.

The reason why these two kinds of genies seek to corrupt or purify the souls of mortals is that they are locked in an eternal war of attrition, desperately trying to increase their numbers and decrease the numbers of their enemy. Souls that started as the worst of society and then found the error of their ways—or, conversely, started as kind and noble but were corrupted in life—are the souls that give rise to noble shubeiks and noble lubeiks, the most powerful of these genies, and the most important soldiers in their never-ending war.

variantrule.name: Rules on Genie Wishes
entries: These rules governing genie wishes have been inspired by previous editions. Feel free to use them in your games to mitigate how much a genie such as a lubeik can influence the flow of the story with their wishes, as well as to distinguish genie wishes, which can be obtained at any point in an adventure and don't theoretically cost anything to produce, from the extremely powerful spell {@spell Wish|XPHB}.

items: Genie wishes can only affect the present. A wish cannot take a creature forward or back in time, and a wish cannot change something that happened in the past or grant information as to what will happen in the future.
Genie wishes cannot grant anything intangible, such as a noble title.
Genie wishes cannot change the feelings or opinions of a creature, such as making one creature fear another.
Genie wishes cannot bring a creature back from the dead or kill a creature.

Genie wishes cannot create something. If the wish is to have a thousand gold pieces, the genie will summon a thousand gold pieces from somewhere else (or, more likely, teleport the creature making the wish to the place where those thousand gold pieces are stored).
Genies cannot grant wishes to other genies, including themselves.
Genie wishes cannot be used to wish for more wishes.
